image.altText: A young Aboriginal man standing on an outback runway in front of a small aircraft and looking serious.

items.synopsis: In some of Australia's most remote communities, where many don't speak English as a first language, an Indigenous community broadcaster is reaching out to learn residents' views about the Indigenous Voice to Parliament ahead of the referendum.

title.children: Damien has travelled Australia talking to communities about the Voice. Here's what he found

image.altText: For Sale signage outside a suburban house.

items.synopsis: New research shows more than 25 per cent of homes sold in Queensland, Victoria and NSW were paid for in cash by older Australians who have benefited from high property prices and are "basically immune" to the effects of rising interest rates.

title.children: With another interest rate rise, there's a large group of home buyers who are 'immune' from its impacts

image.altText: A photo of the Darwin city skyline showing buildings in the CBD on a sunny dry season day.

items.synopsis: The vice-chancellor of the NT's biggest university calls for people to open up spare bedrooms to students, as calls grow for vacant office space to potentially be used as a temporary solution.

title.children: Could vacant offices help solve Darwin's tight student accommodation market?

image.altText: A woman steps into an old, dimly lit hallway.

items.synopsis: The state forced Katelyn apart from her mother, who has dementia, for two years. She says her mother was left without important medical care as her guardian struggled to manage an excessive workload.

title.children: Katelyn's mother is under state care. They left her heart monitor disconnected for 18 months

image.altText: A composite image of Jim Chalmers and Philip Lowe.

items.synopsis: It's not just stretched borrowers being pushed closer to breaking point. The consensus between the treasurer and the RBA governor is also cracking – at least when it comes to the impact wages are having on inflation, writes David Speers.

title.children: When it comes to inflation and wages, Chalmers and Lowe diverge on one pivotal point

image.altText: Wells smiles as she holds an elderly womans hand and listens to her speak.

items.synopsis: The aged care minister leaves the door open for wealthy people to fund their own aged care, or imposing a levy on Australians to pay for rising costs, as baby boomers begin to enter the system.

title.children: 'The boomers are coming': Aged care minister leaves door open for levy for ageing Australia

image.altText: Before and after images show the flood damage

items.synopsis: Satellite images show the extent of the damage as one of the biggest reservoirs of water in the world drains across war-ravaged Ukraine.

title.children: A flood of biblical proportions: Southern Ukraine will be inundated with 36 Sydney Harbours in days

image.altText: A composite of police bodycam of a man holding up a phone near armed officers, and character Jimmy Pesto from Bob's Burgers

items.synopsis: This is The Loop, your quick catch-up for this morning's stories as they happen.

title.children: Bob's Burgers actor arrested over US Capitol riot, and wrestling icon The Iron Sheik dies. Catch up with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Queensland Premier Annastacia Palaszczuk has shared her trauma of suffering a miscarriage, as another woman's harrowing experience sparks an internal health review. Palaszczuk revealed her misscarriage during questioning about allegations that a woman was traumatised by the treatment she received after a painful miscarriage at Ipswich Hospital. "I have also had a miscarriage," the premier tells Nine's Today. "I do know exactly what it's like. It is horrific and stays with you for the rest of your life." Palaszczuk says she was at her home the day she lost her own child. "I had it in my house," she says. "I went to work — I was completely in shock. "This was many, many years ago of course, before I was a politician, but I know the trauma that goes through with women. "It is heartbreaking, it is very hurtful and you're in shock, and you don't know what to do." The personal revelation comes after the state government ordered a full internal review of the Ipswich Hospital.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Queensland Premier Annastacia Palaszczuk shares she suffered a miscarriage

props.alt: Annastacia Palaszczuk wearing a red blazer standing outside.

children.content: Annastacia Palaszcsuk suffered a miscarriage before she became a politician.
(ABC News)
Queensland Premier Annastacia Palaszczuk has shared her trauma of suffering a miscarriage, as another woman's harrowing experience sparks an internal health review.
Palaszczuk revealed her misscarriage during questioning about allegations that a woman was traumatised by the treatment she received after a painful miscarriage at Ipswich Hospital.
"I have also had a miscarriage," the premier tells Nine's Today.
"I do know exactly what it's like. It is horrific and stays with you for the rest of your life."
Palaszczuk says she was at her home the day she lost her own child.
"I had it in my house," she says.
"I went to work — I was completely in shock.
"This was many, many years ago of course, before I was a politician, but I know the trauma that goes through with women.
"It is heartbreaking, it is very hurtful and you're in shock, and you don't know what to do."
The personal revelation comes after the state government ordered a full internal review of the Ipswich Hospital.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: American actor Jay Johnston, best known as the voice of Jimmy Pesto in the animated show Bob's Burgers, has been arrested and charged with joining a mob of Donald Trump supporters who confronted police officers during the US Capitol riot on January 6, 2021, court records show. Johnston was arrested on charges including civil disorder, which is a felony. The FBI says video footage shows Johnston pushing against police and helping rioters who attacked officers, by guarding an entrance to the Capitol in a tunnel on the Lower West Terrace. While the mob attacked police in the tunnel with pepper spray and other weapons, Johnston is said to have helped other rioters near the tunnel pour water on their faces and then joined in pushing against the line of officers. Three associates of Johnston identified him as a riot suspect from photos the FBI which had been published online. The FBI says one of the associates provided investigators with a text message in which Johnston acknowledged being at the Capitol on January 6.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Bob's Burger actor Jay Johnston arrested on Capitol riot charges

props.alt: A composite of a police bodycam screenshot of a man holding up a phone near armed officers, and character Jimmy Pesto from the animated show Bob's Burgers

children.content: (AP: US Justice Department / Disney)
American actor Jay Johnston, best known as
the voice of Jimmy Pesto in the animated show Bob's Burgers
, has been arrested and charged with joining a mob of Donald Trump supporters who confronted police officers during the US Capitol riot on January 6, 2021, court records show.
Johnston was arrested on charges including civil disorder, which is a felony.
The FBI says video footage shows Johnston
pushing against police and helping rioters who attacked officers
, by guarding an entrance to the Capitol in a tunnel on the Lower West Terrace.

While the mob attacked police in the tunnel with pepper spray and other weapons, Johnston is said to have helped other rioters near the tunnel pour water on their faces and then joined in pushing against the line of officers.
Three associates of Johnston identified him as a riot suspect from photos the FBI which had been published online.
The FBI says one of the associates provided investigators with a text message in which Johnston acknowledged being at the Capitol on January 6.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: An earthquake off Cairns has rattled far north Queensland. Geosciences Australia says the 4.3 magnitude quake hit at about a 10:15pm last night, about 125 kilometres off the coast. It has received reports from people feeling the quake in Cairns, Innisfail and Babinda. Sue Richards from Atherton says she'd just got into bed when her windows rattled. "I thought it must be a bit of wind," Richards says. "Then I thought it was earth-moving equipment but I now know what it was." Millaa Millaa resident Wilma tells ABC Local Radio she felt her home west of Cairns shake. "I felt the ground shaking," she says. "I live on the highway and there were no trucks going past at the time."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: An earthquake has also hit near Cairns

props.alt: A map showing the location of an earthquake off the coast of Cairns

children.content: (Geoscience Australia)
An earthquake off Cairns has rattled far north Queensland.
Geosciences Australia says the
4.3 magnitude quake
hit at about a 10:15pm last night, about
125 kilometres off the coast
It has received reports from people feeling the quake in Cairns, Innisfail and Babinda.
Sue Richards
from Atherton
says she'd just got into bed when her windows rattled.
"I thought it must be a bit of wind," Richards says.
"Then I thought it was earth-moving equipment but I now know what it was."
Millaa Millaa resident Wilma tells ABC Local Radio she felt her home west of Cairns shake.
"I felt the ground shaking," she says.
"I live on the highway and there were no trucks going past at the time."

image.altText: Vladimir Putin chairs meeting

items.synopsis: Russian President Vladimir Putin says the destruction of the Kakhovka dam is an "environmental and humanitarian catastrophe" during a call with Turkish counterpart Recep Tayyip Erdoğan.

title.children: Putin calls dam breach a 'catastrophe', Ukraine says it's made advances in Bakhmut

image.altText: A top golf executive sits at a desk in front of a microphone and looks out at reporters at a press conference.

items.synopsis: News of a PGA Tour-LIV Golf union shook the sport to its core, but the unseemly truth is the real merger is with the Saudi Arabian Public Investment Fund, and will likely spell the end for LIV.

title.children: There is no PGA Tour-LIV Golf merger. The truth is much darker than that

image.altText: A woman holds a garden tool.

items.synopsis: Hundreds of people come together, share ideas, and help each other at the Triangle Tool Library in Cobargo, fuelled by the generous donations that poured into the bushfire-affected community after the Black Summer.

title.children: Bustling with people getting advice, this is not a hardware store but a tool library

image.altText: David Warner looks to one side

title.children: Five things we learnt at the WTC Final: From Warner's good start to the emergence of Trav-ball

image.altText: A man wearing all black walks along a line of other men, also wearing black.

items.synopsis: The federal government says it will introduce legislation to ban Nazi symbols and the sale of goods-for-profit featuring Nazi symbols.

title.children: Federal government set to introduce national ban on Nazi symbols

image.altText: A map

items.synopsis: Two strong tremors have rocked Far North Queensland and northern NSW overnight with a 'reasonably significant' 4.3 magnitude and a 3.1 magnitude earthquake rattling homes.

title.children: Twin earthquakes rattle Australia's east coast

image.altText: Harry and Chelsy

items.synopsis: Giving evidence for the second day in court, Prince Harry says he found a tracking device on the car of former girlfriend Chelsy Davy.

title.children: Prince Harry says he found a tracker on Chelsy Davy's car during press storm

image.altText: A young man wearing a red jumper with a blue shirt collar sticking out.

items.synopsis: More than 15 years after taking his seat in parliament, Roger Cook today reaches the top job in state politics. Political reporter Keane Bourke examines what drives WA's 31st premier.

title.children: From student activist, to marathon man: What makes new WA Premier Roger Cook tick?

image.altText: Young female bartender pulls a pint

items.synopsis: Australians aren't drinking like we used to. Yet, despite parallels to tobacco use, some experts say alcohol's history and place in society mean it'll remain indefinitely.

title.children: Why this expert says we'll always drink, even when we know it's harmful for us

image.altText: Performers taking part in an art show.

items.synopsis: The latest "blatant agenda to bring hell to earth" in sleepy old Hobart is about to kick off — and, true to form, has timed the pressing of the outrage button to perfection.

title.children: Dark Mofo does it again with outrage summoned on command

image.altText: Forensic experts work with several bags of human remains extracted from the bottom of a ravine by a helicopter.

items.synopsis: As many as eight young workers are confirmed dead in Mexico after they apparently tried to quit jobs at a call centre operated by a violent drug cartel that targeted Americans in a real estate scam.

title.children: Human remains found in bags are missing call centre staff, Mexican authorities confirmed

image.altText: Dan Caffrey standing outside of his house and solar panels

items.synopsis: Researchers say rising electricity costs are pushing some home owners to replace their solar panels prematurely, increasing the need for bespoke recycling facilities to avoid them going to waste.

title.children: Premature replacement of landfill-polluting solar panels driven by rising power costs, researchers warn

image.altText: A bald man in a suit and red tie speaks into a microphone while siting at a desk in a room decorated with timber.

items.synopsis: Consulting firm KPMG has labelled the behaviour of its competitor PwC disturbing and unacceptable and proposed a list of reforms as part of a Senate inquiry into the integrity of consultants engaged by the federal government.

title.children: 'Sleeping at the wheel': Treasury response to PwC scandal criticised as KPMG proposes reforms

image.altText: An image of a small carpark next to a Middle Arm boat ramp.

items.synopsis: NT government documents show so-called blue hydrogen requiring natural gas will play a significant role at the Middle Arm Sustainable Development Precinct on Darwin Harbour.

title.children: Documents show natural gas could play major role in $1.5b Middle Arm precinct

image.altText: A female Aedes aegypti mosquito bites someone's skin.

items.synopsis: The Northern Territory has recorded seven cases and two deaths from Murray Valley encephalitis (MVE) this year, as the health department urges people to protect themselves against mosquito bites.

title.children: Outbreak of mosquito-borne disease in the NT sparks health warning

image.altText: A picture of different apps on a phone including ChatGPT

items.synopsis: Scientific papers could be the next ChatGPT battleground. Now researchers say they've developed a tool that is up to 99 per cent accurate at detecting when it's used.

title.children: New ChatGPT-detector 'most accurate yet' say scientists. But will it work in the real world?

image.altText: An elderly married couple warmly embrace while smiling.

items.synopsis: As a GP, Dion Manthorpe looked after South Australian communities for decades. The 95-year-old was battling cancer when he started to access the state's voluntary assisted dying scheme.

title.children: After caring for people for most of his life, Dion was 95 when he accessed voluntary assisted dying

image.altText: Three tall buildings at the end of a road

items.synopsis: A row over a proposed 855-dwelling development which would house 2,000 residents at Zetland is being seen as a test for the New South Wales government in the battle over Sydney development.

title.children: Sydney needs more homes — but for some in this part of town, development is a dirty word

image.altText: Peter Dutton sits in the House of Representatives

title.children: Dutton denies shadow ministers misrepresented federal court judges during Voice debate

image.altText: Man walks on street

items.synopsis: The former NSW Labor minister and convicted paedophile is being treated for multiple injuries after the incident on Tuesday afternoon.

image.altText: A young Asian woman with long dark hair poses for a selfie.

items.synopsis: The mother of slain Melbourne woman Ju Zhang comes face-to-face with her daughter's killer in the Supreme Court, calling for the harshest of punishments to be handed down.

title.children: Tip worker who found Melbourne woman's body tells court he 'cannot believe' cruelty of her murder

image.altText: Canada wildfire US

items.synopsis: Smoke from Canadian wildfires pours into the US East Coast and Midwest, covering the capitals of both nations in an unhealthy haze.

title.children: New York City air pollution eight times higher than normal after being blanketed in smoke from Canadian wildfires

image.altText: Pope Francis raises his hand and holds a white book in front of him

items.synopsis: Pope Francis underwent the surgery to repair a hernia in his abdominal wall and is expected to remain at hospital for several days.

title.children: Pope Francis emerges from three-hour abdominal surgery without complications

image.altText: Lightning across a dark sky on a beach with a jetty

items.synopsis: In a complete reverse of the cold pattern of southerly winds in May, we are now seeing one of the warmest starts to winter on record.

title.children: Unseasonable storms bring warmest start to Australian winter in decades
